<p>Gentlefolk,</p>
<p>I=
 haven't posted here for a while, but many of you know me as having bee=
n active to varying degrees in the REST community for about 6 years now. I =
have some significant experience implementing REST in machine to machine en=
vironments (browser free environments) in backend business systems, realtim=
e safety-related control systems, and a number of other esoteric environmen=
ts that involve leading people and negotiating internal and business to bus=
iness interfaces with people with varying levels of REST expertise and enth=
usiasm. Over the last few years I have been working with a number of others=
 on the title mentioned in the subject line.</p>




<p>It's a title I =
don't expect to pass by this list without criticism. It uses vocabulary=
 that is often more on the SOA side than on the REST side. It focuses on RE=
ST "service contracts" (the set of urls exposed by a server and t=
he server-specific meaning of standard methods and media types in those res=
ources) as a standard tool for governing "REST services" as part =
of an overall service inventory. It focuses almost entirely on machine to m=
achine interaction within the context of IT assets of a single enterprise. =
It doesn't deal much with browsers or mashups and it even spends a sign=
ificant amount of time addressing issues like transactions and pub/sub. Per=
haps for some the very fact that Thomas Erl's name is on the cover well=
 push some buttons :)</p>




<p>Nevertheless we collectively and I in part=
icular have worked hard not to compromise on REST principles and constraint=
s while still making the content accessible to SOA people and the general p=
opulation. Within this context of heavy machine to machine interaction we d=
eal with defining a uniform interface to cover an inventory of services wit=
hin a particular enterprise, and how that should relate to service contract=
s and to broader standardisation efforts. We look to move past SOA's tr=
aditional limit of increasing intrinsic interoperability only within a give=
n inventory and instead look for standard methods and media types to increa=
se interoperability to more massive scales.</p>




<p>We have sought to ke=
ep hypermedia core to the practice of building inventories of services and =
their related customers and to minimise coupling while also being explicit =
about why we do this. We have sought to drive a hard line on the stateless =
constraint and what that means to the aforementioned patterns of transactio=
ns (promoting compensating over atomic) and pub/sub (promoting cached polli=
ng and delta encoding).</p>




<p>Some of you have already seen the materi=
al in various stages of completion as have many SOA guys. Over the last six=
 months or so the manuscript changed significantly as we worked that feedba=
ck into the finished product.</p>




<p>No book is perfect, but I hope thi=
s one will end up bringing the REST and SOA worlds together in a closer und=
erstanding without compromising one iota of what is important to each. I&#3=
9;m confident that despite the unfamiliar wording, context and audience tha=
t the book is written to be applied to that at its heart is a true applicat=
ion of REST constraints and to every possible extent a true application of =
the years of experience the REST community has developed.</p>




<p>The bo=
ok is available in ebook and hard cover:<br>
Amazon - <a href=3D"http://amz=
n.com/0137012519" target=3D"_blank">http://amzn.com/0137012519</a><br>

omas-Erl/e/9780137012510" target=3D"_blank">http://search.barnesandnoble.co=
m/SOA-with-REST/Thomas-Erl/e/9780137012510</a> (seriously? No permalink?)<b=
r>



Home - <a href=3D"http://servicetechbooks.com/rest" target=3D"_blank"=
>http://servicetechbooks.com/rest</a></p>
<p>Comments, discussion and criti=
cism (timidly) welcome. I can't think of a better place to discuss the =
end result than this list.<br>
</p>
